This report was prepared by a team consisting of N. Huda, Project Implementation Officer, PRM 
(Team Leader); H.J. Yu, Principal Programs Officer, SAOC; and S. Nanwani, Senior Counsel, 
OGC.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Despite Pakistan’s long history of public sector development programs, the country’s 
project  implementation  capacity  continues  to  remain  weak,  leading  to  delayed  project 
completion and ineffective use of aid resources. Following an agreement reached during the 
2001 Country Portfolio Review Mission (CPRM) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the 
Government has requested ADB technical assistance (TA) to identify the weaknesses in the 
portfolio management and monitoring system, help streamline the procedures, and strengthen 
the capacity for effective portfolio monitoring. The TA is included in ADB’s country strategy and 
program  for  2002.  The  TA  Fact-Finding  Mission,  fielded  in  August  2002,  reached  an 
understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  and 
implementation arrangements for the TA1. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.     ADB’s Medium-Term Country Strategy for Pakistan (2002–2006) is based on overarching 
development objective of poverty reduction, long-term strategic framework, and lessons learned 
from experience in Pakistan. The incidence of poverty in Pakistan has increased from 26.6% in 
FY1993 to 32.2% in FY1999, and the number of poor people has increased by over 12 million 
during this period. The incidence of poverty is estimated to be significantly higher today than in 
1998-1999 due to slow economic growth and a severe drought for two years. The key areas of 
ADB’s strategic priorities are sustainable pro-poor growth, inclusive of social development, and 
good governance. The major focus of the ADB strategy is to build the capacity of governance 
institutions and promote efficient and effective use of available resources.     
 
3.  Inadequate  Portfolio  Management  Capacity.  The  Government's  development 
investment program has increased substantially over the years, both in terms of finance and 
number of projects in the portfolio. The PSDP allocation for FY2002 amounts to Rs130 billion 
(equivalent  to  $2.10  billion)  for  over  600  projects.  The  composition  of  the  portfolio  has 
significantly changed in terms of sector priorities, with focus on poverty reduction, governance, 
social development, and beneficiary and stakeholder participation. As a result, the capacity 
problem has become the most serious factor constraining line ministries and executing agencies 
from effectively implementing projects and meeting their development objectives.   
 
4.  The PSDP is largely funded by external agencies. From the start of ADB lending 
operations to Pakistan in 1968 through 31 December 2001, ADB has approved 183 public 
sector loans totaling $11.45 billion. As of 31 May 2002, ADB’s portfolio consisted of 49 active 
loans with an undisbursed balance of $4.2 billion. ADB's annual lending to Pakistan increased 
substantially over the last two years, and was $710.0 million in 2000 and $956.8 million in 2001, 
against an average of $500 million to $600 million in the past. The 2002 lending program is 
expected reach $1.0 billion and the pipeline for the next 3 years is $2.4 billion, an average of 
$800 million a year.   
 
5.  Project  Implementation  Delays.  Project  implementation  delays  remain  a  familiar 
feature  of  ADB’s  portfolio  in  Pakistan.  Most  projects  have  faced  persistent  implementation 
problems  and  suffered  average  start-up  delays  of  over  2  years  due  to  delays  in  loan 
effectiveness and setting up of the project implementation units. Such long start-up delays 
adversely affect the project implementation schedule and require an average 3 year extension 
of loans to complete projects. Frequent transfers of project directors and other key staff, lack of

qualified staff, poor accountability, and the complex bureaucratic decision-making process also 
seriously affect project implementation. In ADB’s experience, on average, 5 project directors are 
changed over a project period of 5 - 6 years. The system does not encourage the commitment 
of project directors to accelerate work by proactive steps to minimize delays in contract awards.   
The  selection  criteria  for  recruiting  key  project  staff  are  not  based  on  needs  for  project 
management skills and experience. Project directors are in many cases appointed in addition to 
their other responsibilities, rather than on a full time basis, and against understandings reached 
at appraisal. 
 
6.  Delays  in  Procurement  and  Consultant  Selection.  Due  to  unfamiliarity  with 
procurement  procedures  and  lengthy  approval  formalities  within  the  line  ministries  and 
departments, contract awards are inordinately delayed. Contract awards for medium-sized 
procurement take about 21 months, and recruitment of consultants takes 15- 24 months. As a 
result, annual targets for contract awards and disbursement are not fully achieved, although 
targets are generally set low taking into account the country’s systemic weaknesses and track 
record of underperformance. The average contract awards ratio over the last 5 years (1997–
2001), was 19.82% against the ADB-wide average of 22.86%. The average disbursement ratio 
during the same period was, however, slightly better primarily due to fast-disbursing program 
loans. For 2001, total contract awards and disbursement projections were $314.8 million and 
$503.8  million,  respectively.  Against  these  projections,  actual  achievements  amounted  to 
$391.4 (124%) in contract awards, and $512.3 million (102%) in disbursement, including a lump 
sum  amount  under  program  loans  of  contract  awards  valued  at  $299.6  million  and 
disbursements for $331.9 million. Excluding program loans, actual achievements for contract 
awards and disbursement during 2001 were below the annual projections, accounting for 97% 
and 81% of projections, respectively. Although annual contract awards and disbursements 
improved recently, the overall performance is not satisfactory given the enhanced assistance 
level and long experience of ADB operations in the country.   
 
7.  Poor Accounting and Auditing. Project accounts are not properly maintained due to 
inadequate capacity among executing agencies, which also affects portfolio performance. Poor 
accounting practices raise questions about irregularities and lack of transparency leading to 
delays in auditing of project accounts and poor quality of audits. The Audit Office of the Director 
General lacks adequate capacity to audit project accounts and submit audited project accounts, 
and audited project accounts and financial statements are usually delayed. For 2001, only 33% 
of ADB loans had complied fully and on time with requirements for audited project accounts and 
financial statements, while 17% had partly or not complied, and complied late 50%. Timely 
submission of audit reports and maintenance of high accounting and auditing standards are 
required under ADB’s Anticorruption Policy, and the capacity of project accounts staff and the 
staff of the Office of the Auditor General needs strengthening to do so.  
 
8.  Inadequate Attention to Development Impacts. Because of implementation delays, 
poor management, and inadequate attention to cross- cutting policy issues, projects in Pakistan 
are not effective in achieving development impacts.  ADB’s postevaluation findings have shown 
that the development impact of many completed projects has been much less than anticipated 
and the overall performance of the Pakistan portfolio is not satisfactory when compared to that 
of the ADB-wide portfolio. Based on ADB’s postevaluation findings, as reflected in the project 
performance audit reports circulated during 1996–2001, none of Pakistan’s 19 projects was 
highly successful, 31.6% were successful, 52.6% were partly successful, and 15.8% were 
unsuccessful,  compared  to  the  ADB-wide performance of  13.8% highly successful, 39.0% 
successful, 33.3% partly successful, and 13.9% unsuccessful.

3
9.  Weak Monitoring and Evaluation. The monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system works 
mainly within the institutional structure of the Federal Planning and Development Division 
(FPDD) through its Project Wing and the provincial planning and development departments or 
board (PPDDs) through their M&E units. In addition, the Economic Affairs Division (EAD) 
monitors the foreign-aided projects, and the key line ministries conduct periodic review of 
project implementation. Although the Project Wing and the M&E units are mandated to carry out 
M&E  work,  they  lack  required  institutional  support,  qualified  staff,  resources,  and  proper 
direction to function effectively. The current project management information system (MIS) is too 
weak to ensure a constant flow of information on the implementation and portfolio management 
issues to the key Government officials, the Project Wing and EAD at the federal level, and the 
provincial M&E units. The Project Wing has recently introduced a quarterly progress report on 
projects  providing  basic  data  and  implementation  progress;  the  reports  are  reviewed 
interdepartmentally and selected problem projects are discussed at the highest level in the 
Government. However, this monitoring system mainly focuses on the financial progress of 
projects  against  annual  budget  allocations  and  funds  release,  with  little  attention  to 
implementation  issues  and  remedial  measures  for  achieving  development  objectives  and 
impacts.  To  improve  the  M&E  system,  the  Project  Wing  plans  to  introduce  a  detailed 
questionnaire for collecting project data, and institute computerized code for all projects.        
 
10.  Through regular biannual CPRMs, ADB has raised generic implementation issues to the 
Government's attention for remedial steps. Despite specific actions agreed during the CPRMs, 
the  portfolio  performance  has  not  shown  any  significant  improvement,  particularly  in 
development  impacts.  Based  on  CPRM  experience,  the  Pakistan  Resident  Mission  has 
undertaken new initiative to improve portfolio performance and close interactions with executing 
agencies in 2001 by quarterly provincial project review meetings which are chaired by the 
provincial ministers of finance and planning. Similarly, for umbrella projects, quarterly federal 
project review meetings are held at EAD. The meetings have been effective in discussing 
outstanding project issues and drawing more attention of senior officials to the necessary action.  
ADB also closely coordinates with other external agencies that express concern about delays in 
project implementation and poor portfolio performance, and stress the need for urgently taking 
corrective measures. However, the Government and funding agencies have yet to take a broad-
based initiative to address this problem, and action has been limited to project- or province-
specific efforts.    
 
11.  The Government recognizes the need to improve portfolio performance and has initiated 
steps  to  identify  weaknesses  in  the  portfolio  management  and  monitoring  system  and 
recommend the necessary streamlining and strengthening. The Government, as committed at 
the Pakistan Development Forum held in Paris in April 2002, has established a high-level task 
force to examine project implementation issues and recommend measures for effective use of 
aid resources. Therefore, the proposed TA is timely and it will reinforce Pakistan Resident 
Mission’s efforts through CPRMs, and the quarterly provincial project review meetings and 
federal project review meetings to sustain improvement in portfolio performance.  
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output   
12.  The TA will strengthen the portfolio performance and monitoring capacity of the Project 
Wing of FPDD and the M&E units and cells of PPDDs and PPDB in four provinces: Balochistan, 
North-West Frontier Province (NWFP), Punjab, and Sindh. The TA will help (i) streamline the 
system of internal clearances, including synchronizing the Government's project document with

4   
 
ADB loan documents; (ii) improve the efficiency of the system to recruit and retain key project 
staff  during  project  implementation;  (iii)  expedite  procurement  and  consultant  selection  by 
simplifying  decision-making  procedures  and  delegation  of  authority;  (iv)  strengthen  the 
monitoring system of portfolio performance by developing a comprehensive MIS on key project 
activities for sustained information flow among stakeholders, mainly through the Project Wing at 
the federal level, and linking the MIS with the provincial M&E units of PPDDs and PPDB; and  
(v) assign core staff responsibility and provide training to concerned officials for effective 
portfolio monitoring. Given the nature of issues to be addressed and the need to institutionalize 
the capacity building, a follow-up TA will be required. The main focus of this TA will be to 
strengthen the capacity of the Project Wing and the M&E units, which would need to be further 
deepened under a follow-up TA.          
 
13.  The  TA  will  review  the  Government's  internal  approval  procedures  for  project 
implementation matters. The weaknesses and reasons for delayed project implementation will 
be identified, and the required remedial steps taken. The rules and decision-making authorities 
on project implementation and related matters will be examined, and necessary modifications 
and improvements recommended and pursued for implementation. The TA will develop a 
comprehensive data base for key project activities and financial performance to strengthen the 
monitoring system of FPDD, PPDDs, and PPDB through an effective MIS with appropriate 
networking arrangements established for constant flow of information to the those concerned in 
the decision-making system, including EAD, the line ministries, and departments.  Thus, the TA 
will integrate the monitoring system with the decision makers at higher levels and those directly 
involved  in  project  implementation  for  efficient  portfolio  management  and  improved 
performance. The TA will identify core staff and logistic support required for the portfolio 
monitoring system, define their responsibilities, and provide extensive training for capacity 
building within the Project Wing, EAD, the M&E Units at PPDDs and PPDB and key line 
agencies.     
 
14.  The TA will also provide streamlined project implementation procedures, a strengthened 
monitoring  system  with  comprehensive  data  base,  a  pool  of  well-trained  core  staff  for 
internalizing capacity building, and outcome-based portfolio performance monitoring indicators. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.   The  TA  will  be  implemented  by  a  team  of  experienced  international  and  domestic 
consultants.  The  consultants  will  work  closely  with  the  Government’s  counterpart  staff,  in 
consultation with the key stakeholders involved in the decision making for and implementation of 
projects. The consultants work will be closely supervised by ADB, and guided and monitored by 
the Government through a high-level federal steering committee and provincial coordination 
committees. Workshops will be organized to solicit views of the stakeholders at different levels 
of the Government on project implementation and portfolio management issues and agree on 
remedial actions.   
 
16.  Based on review of existing systems and procedures, the consultants will undertake 
well-defined and sequenced activities, e.g., (i) a situation analysis including institutional set up; 
(ii) training needs assessment, training manuals on project management and procurement 
matters, and hands-on-training for concerned staff; (iii) development of simplified project and 
procurement approval procedures; (iv) development of an MIS and outcome-based monitoring 
indicators; and (v) preparation of an action plan for institutionalizing the MIS and a plan for 
implementing various recommendations during the TA and after its completion on a sustained 
basis.

5
 
C.  Cost Estimates and Financing  
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $815,000 equivalent comprising a foreign 
exchange cost of $286,000 and a local currency cost of $529,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. ADB financing will cover the total 
foreign exchange cost and $364,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will 
finance the remaining local currency cost of $165,000 equivalent in kind for the items prescribed 
in Appendix 2. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  FPDD will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The implementing agencies will be the 
Project Wing, and PPDDs and PPDB in four provinces. A federal TA steering committee will be 
headed by the secretary of FPDD, with members from EAD, the Finance Division, lead line 
ministries, and the Auditor General’s Office. The committee will meet regularly to provide  
guidance on TA implementation, and will be responsible for implementing the recommendations 
of the TA.  At the provincial level, a TA coordination committee in each province will be headed 
by the PPDD additional chief secretary, and chairperson of the PPDB, with members from other 
lead departments and agencies.       
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months, and is expected to commence in January 
2003 and be completed in March 2004. FPDD will establish a TA implementation office under its 
Project Wing for overall implementation, coordination, and monitoring of the TA. The office will 
be headed by federal project director. The PPDDs and PPDB will establish TA implementation 
cells and will appoint a project coordinator to head each cell. In addition, EAD will coordinate the 
TA implementation by interfacing with the TA implementation office and TA implementation cells 
to complement the task force related work on project implementation issues, and will be 
provided with necessary logistical support. The TA will require the services of one international 
consultant for a total of 9 person-months for systems streamlining, procurement, and training. 
The consultant will be the team leader. The domestic consultants will be required for 53 person-
months for project monitoring, procurement, MIS, and financial management and accounting. 
Outline terms of reference of the consultants are in Appendix 3. The international consultant will 
be recruited on an individual basis and the domestic consultants through a domestic firm using 
ADB’s quality- and cost-based selection procedures and according to ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic 
consultants.  The  method  of  simplified  technical  proposal  will  be  used  for  the  domestic 
consultants.  Equipment to be provided under the TA will be procured under supervision of the 
consultant team leader in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
IV.          THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.     The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Pakistan  for  Strengthening  Portfolio  Performance  and  Monitoring,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.          Team leader and system streamlining and procurement and training      
                   specialist 
 
1.              The team leader will be international consultant for 9 person-months, and will  
                  provide intermittent inputs in two or three stages, as appropriate.  
 
 2.              As a team leader, the consultant will do the following: 
  
(i)  Develop  a  detailed  methodology  and  comprehensive  work  plan  in 
consultation  with  key  stakeholders  and  assume  overall  responsibility  for 
timely implementation of the technical assistance (TA) in accordance with the 
terms of reference.   
 
(ii)  Coordinate  and  supervise  the  work  of  all  team  members  and  provide 
technical  expertise  in  the  management  and  implementation  issues  of 
development projects portfolio.  
 
(iii)  Assure the overall lead role for coordinating TA implementation in the federal 
Government and the four provincial governments.  
 
(iv)  Conduct  policy  dialogue  and  technical  discussions  with  the  federal  and 
provincial governments.  
 
(v)  Consult with other key external funding agencies on project implementation 
problems and measures for strengthening portfolio performance.   
 
(vi)  Formulate  a  time-bound  action  plan  on  the  implementation  of  various 
recommendations of the TA, based on outcome-based monitoring indicators 
and agreements reached with the concerned agencies such as the Project 
Wing  of  the  federal  planning  and  development  division  (FPDD),  the 
Economic Affairs Division (EAD), and the monitoring and evaluation (M&E) 
units  of  provincial  planning  and  development  departments  (PPDDs)  and 
provincial planning and development (PPDB).  
 
(vii)  Closely follow up the implementation of the pilot action plan starting after six 
months of the TA implementation.   
  
 
3.         As a system specialist, the consultant will do the following: 
             
(i)  Review  the  Government’s  administrative  systems  of  processing  and 
approving  projects  covering  the  preparation  and  revision  of  the  project 
concept paper and project document (PC-1). Suggest measures to streamline 
the  procedures  and  synchronize  project  concept  papers  and  the  project 
proforma with the loan documents of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).

Appendix 3  11
(ii)  Review the procedures for releasing ADB funds and issuing commitment 
letters, and suggest measures for improving imprest accounts operations. 
 
(iii)  Prepare  a  project  compendium  compiling  all  existing  administrative 
procedures,  rules,  orders,  and  decisions  on  project  processing  and 
implementation matters issued at various levels of federal and provincial 
     governments; and recommend a time-bound action plan for streamlining the  
     process of administrative approvals. 
 
(iv)  Review the selection, appointment, and retention criteria for project directors 
and key project staff. Suggest measures to (a) strengthen selection criteria 
considering the management and technical skills, (b) introduce transparency 
into the recruitment process and retention procedures, and (c) introduce an 
incentive system (e.g., in situ career development and project allowance). 
 
(v)  Review the financial, administrative, and procurement authorities of project 
directors.  Suggest  appropriate  delegation  of  such  authorities  based  on 
detailed  review  and  recommend  measures  to  effectively  exercise  the 
authorities delegated to project directors. 
 
(vi)   Assess the existing procedures and systems of recurrent budget allocations 
and approval of staff positions for completed project facilities  and suggest 
measures for ensuring full operations without delay.
